skills.name: Given a description of an ascending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence
Use a graphical representation of a sequence to find a term in the sequence
Identify relationships between two sequences when given graphically
Identify the ordered pair when plotting two sequences against each other

explanations.A: Reading the ordered pairs from the graph, we get: (1,0), (2,2), (3,4), (4,6). We can see that the terms from Sequence A are increasing by 1 each time. And the terms from Sequence B are increasing by 2 each time. Therefore, it is true that to get from one point to the next, we move across 1 and up 2 each time. You will need to carefully check every ordered pair with every statement to find the one false statement.
explanations.B: Reading the ordered pairs from the graph, we get: (1,0), (2,2), (3,4), (4,6). If we multiply each term in Sequence A by 2 and then subtract 2, we get: 0, 2, 4, 6....which are the corresponding terms in Sequence B. Therefore this statement is true. explanations.A: Reading the ordered pairs from the graph, we get: (1,0), (2,3), (3,6), (4,9). If the x-coordinates are Sequence A and the y-coordinates are Sequence B, we can see that 3 is in both sequences, even though (3,3) is not a point on the graph.
explanations.B: Reading the ordered pairs from the graph, we get: (1,0), (2,3), (3,6), (4,9). If the x-coordinates are Sequence A and the y-coordinates are Sequence B, we can see that A is greater for the first point, but B is greater for each of the others. Therefore, this is the false statement.
explanations.C: Reading the ordered pairs from the graph, we get: (1,0), (2,3), (3,6), (4,9). Multiplying each of the Sequence A terms (x-coordinates) by 3 and subtracting 3 gives the corresponding term of Sequence B (y-coordinate), so this statement is true.
explanations.D: We can see from the graph that moving 1 across and 3 up will get us from each green point to the next green point, so this statement is true. We are looking for a false statement. It might help to write out the ordered pairs to see the terms of each sequence.
